page.title: 01Torridon,general review.
page.content: {The National Trust for Scotland}are the proprietors of the land,most of which is mountainous, much of it over 1,000 metres;some parts are boggy or grassland.Most houses are private detatched, strung along the landward side of the road whichskirts Loch Torridon. Amenities are:a sub Post Office,phone kiosk, Primary School, Doctor's surgery,village Hall, war memorial,camp site,telephone exchange, Youth Hostel and mountain rescue post, public conveniences, National Trust countryside centre and deer museum and a former farm,now used for grazing.The road is mostly single track apart from a small stretch of double track on which there is a bride crossing the river which runs beside the road much of the way.The area is very scenic with climbing and geological interests a few small coniferous woods and sea
